By Thorr on Wednesday, January 30, 2008 - 06:26 am:

Ok, I have a template for presenting the monster data found in the Perfect Guide. My thought for presenting the information is this -

1) Under the FAQ Section, I will create a section for Monster data.

2) Make a Post for all 24 Base Breeds
3) Each post will contain the Information for the base breed (Tech gaining list, breed trait, availability, training tendencies) and the data block for all the sub breeds.

I will start with Abisu as a sample and see how it works.

By Thorr on Wednesday, January 30, 2008 - 08:48 am:

By Thorr on Wednesday, January 30, 2008 - 08:52 am:

Note on the techniques list -

The techniques each have a name, but it's really not worth translating. The Class column shows Basic Strong and Unique.
Basic moves are moves that most breeds can acquire. These would be things like Claw, Bite, Kick, etc.
Strong moves are advanced techs that are less common amongst other breeds.
Unique moves are techs that only this particular breed can acquire.

The Final column shows where you must train in order to acquire the Tech. I am not sure if techs have to be acquired sequentially, but I doubt it. Rank -does- figure into it, though, since you have to be of certain ranks to train in certain locations.

By GM on Wednesday, January 30, 2008 - 01:48 pm:

Looking even better now.

Regarding the likes/dislikes table, I think the current layout of dislikes immediately following likes is a bit crude-looking, especially since the breeds apparently have only one significant dislike. It would look much better if you had the likes and dislikes on separate lines.

By Thorr on Thursday, January 31, 2008 - 05:02 am:

It's a linear chart. It's copied exactly the way it shows in the book. The line of items from left to right go from Like the most to Hate the most. This applies to the treats line and then the food line.
Like<------------Indifferent----------->Dislike

The whole layout for the main breed info is copied exactly as shown in the guide. It's much easier on me to translate them when I have a direct visual reference.

By GM on Thursday, January 31, 2008 - 09:51 am:
